subject: Center Stage
event:
Here's your chance to ask me that question you've always wanted an answer to.

Starting tomorrow, I will be appearing for the next five days on the Center Stage forum of the Barnes & Noble Book Club.  I'll be logging on at least once each day to field whatever questions my readers and the B&N customers have left for me.  Now, I'm not going to promise to answer all of the questions.  I will give it my best college try, but a lot depends on how many questions are actually posted.  Sometimes this blog generates hundreds of comments in just a few hours, and that's obviously more than I can handle... but if the number is more manageable, well, I'll see what I can do.

You'll find Center Stage at http://bookclubs.barnesandnoble.com/bn/board?board.id=CenterStage if you would like to post a question, or just read the ongoing discussions.

I will actually have three topics for my very own.  One for INSIDE STRAIGHT and the Wild Card series, one for A SONG OF ICE AND FIRE and all my other books, and one about my experiences writing for television and film, including BEAUTY AND THE BEAST, TWILIGHT ZONE, and my series-that-never-was, DOORWAYS.  So be sure to post your question in the right topic.

comments.article:
EDIT: I just realized you were talking about the forum and not this blog entry, but I'll leave my comment anyway in quiet hope. I can't log onto the forum because of my current (international) location. Thank you!

How much of your creative process is editing and re-editing? As a percentage, do you usually bang out some work, buff it once or twice, and think "great!" or do you spend hours agonizing over perfecting a sentence? Has your writing style changed significantly over time?

Oh, how fun! You answered one of my questions last time you did one of these type things, though, so maybe I'll let someone else have a chance. *g*

...Unless I suddenly think of a really good one.

BTW, thanks so much for putting up the auction items for Alzheimer's charity (did I thank you for this before? Oh goodness, I can't even remember). As Vice-Chair of the North American Discworld Convention, I am of course excited by anything that could help Terry or the cause.

.. but it may not be book related.

Im just wondering if you can give any tips on how you get Parris to love you so much that she always goes home to you? Its not that I want to steal her from you or anything like that! (well, maybe a little bit) ;-P

An Irish fan.
xxooxx

comments.article: Roy Dotrice did a fantastic job of reading the first three "Song of Ice & Fire" books. I was disappointed not to find him reading the forth. Don't get me wrong, John Lee is an excellent reader in his on right. It's just that I've gotten use to immediately recognizing the many characters by the voice inflections Roy gives them. I recognize the characters before Roy reads that this is Tyrion speaking or Arya speaking. John Lee just does not have much distinction between the many different characters. John is a good reader, but Roy is superb, a one in ten thousand reader. I hope you will consider using Roy for the last two books of the series. Thank you for taking the time to read my comments. Needless to say, I love your writting. You are a fantastic writer! Live long and prosper.
comments.subject: Books on tape reader, Roy Dotrice

comments.article:
hello mr Martin
Big hello from Croatia, the country with possibly the worst translation of your wonderful Song of Ice and Fire.
Luckily the English version is available.

It seems i was late for adding my question on those boards. Ill try now but i understand if you dont answer me.

Will there be more stories or info about Smiling Knight and all that time?

One question about your writing style.
It seems to me your prefer to end most chapters in a book with cliffhangers.
That has some negative effect on the reader because by the time he gets to the end of the next chapter another cliffhanger is there and so on and on and on, making it very hard to get to solutions of situations because new cliffhangers constantly replace older ones.

The way i read your books is: i read them whole first time and then i reread them again following specific characters a few more times. :)
But would it be much trouble to just end some chapters without cliffhanger? To just let it come to some peaceful part so we can get onto another character without feeling torn to bits inside? Every time?

And could you just threaten Croatian translator to stop translating names of the places in the books? Please?
Because kids these days in Croatia have no idea that Winterfell is called Winterfell... they think its called something like Sharp winter(ish)... translated back to English. And i dont even want to mention the rest of the places, cities, rivers and lands... they even translate the word Lord to some inappropriate Croatian title... its horrible i tell you!

thanks...
comments.subject: few things...

comments.article:
LOL! You are the lucky ones. I gather the Hungarian version of Winterfell is something like "frosty". (That single word was enough to convince me never to read the translations :D)

They really could just leave the names as they are. I mean, no one would try to translate them if the story took place in Mediaeval England...
